title-group.article-title: A meso-scale analysis method for the simulation of nonlinear damage and failure behavior of reinforced concrete members

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Urban Security and Disaster Engineering of Ministry of Education, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China
2School of Civil and Resource Engineering, University of Western Australia, Perth, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Liu Jin, Key Laboratory of Urban Security and Disaster Engineering of Ministry of Education, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing, China. Email: kinglew2007@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Based on the meso-mechanical analysis model of concrete material, a meso-scale numerical approach is developed for the simulation of failure behavior and nonlinear mechanical properties of reinforced concrete members. The present meso-mechanical approach, i.e. so-called the meso-element equivalent method, is capable of capturing the important characteristic of concrete heterogeneity. Two reinforced concrete columns of different sizes subjected to uniaxial compression is simulated using both a macro-scale homogeneous and a meso-scale heterogeneous model to illustrate the rationality of the meso-scale approach. In the simulations, perfect bond between concrete and reinforcing steel is assumed. The meso-scale simulation results are compared with the macro-scale results as well as the experimental observations. Results of the simulation at the meso-scale are in good agreement with experiments in terms of the failure patterns and the global mechanical properties, which demonstrate the rationality and accuracy of the present meso-mechanical approach. The present meso-scale approach can well simulate not only the macroscopic mechanical properties of the two reinforced concrete columns but also their failure process, such as the buckling behavior of the longitudinal reinforcement, the necking fracture of the stirrups, the broken positions of concrete, etc. Besides that it can be concluded from the numerical results that the present meso-mechanical approach can be extended to investigate the size effect in reinforced concrete members.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Reinforced concrete (RC) has become one of the most important building materials and has been widely used in many types of engineering structures such as bridges, dams, off-shore platforms, nuclear power plants, etc. The safety and serviceability assessment of these engineering structures necessitates the development of accurate and reliable methods and models for their analysis. With the development of science and technology, the increase of span and height, the diversification of these structures, the size of RC members are becoming larger and larger, and thus the load-carrying capacity is getting higher and higher. In addition, the rise in cost of structures encourages engineers to seek more economical alternative designs often resorting to innovative construction methods without lowering the safety of the structures. Therefore, careful and detailed structure safety analysis and numerical simulation become more important.

The global mechanical properties and failure mechanism of RC are of fundamental importance to the analysis of these RC engineering structures. RC structures consist of two materials with different characteristics, namely, concrete and steel. The overall mechanical properties of RC members are determined by concrete and steel. Steel can be considered as a homogeneous material and its material properties are simple and easy to describe. Unlike steel materials, concrete is a kind of heterogeneous composite material composed of aggregates, micro-cracks, voids, mortar matrix, etc. These inherent features make the mechanical properties of concrete hard to be defined, and thus the damage process and fracture mechanism are extremely complex. A size effect has been confirmed for concrete-like brittle materials and thus, it ought to exist in RC components. Although the size effect has been taken into account by RC structure design code, the mechanical mechanism is still not very clear. Thus, further research in this regard is still needed.

As it is known, tests of the effect of structural size are the best way to decide whether the size effect exists in concrete members. Lots of experimental work has been conducted to investigate the size effect in RC members. Bažant and Kwon (1994) reported the results of a series of tests of geometrically similar pin-ended tied RC columns of different sizes, and their experimental observations proved the presence of size effect in RC columns. Lu et al. (1999) conducted several tests of 1 : 5.5-scale model frames and found smaller scale columns exhibited a cracking pattern more concentrated around the mid-height stub than the larger scale ones. Němeček and Bittnar (2004) carried out an experimental and numerical work on three different sizes of geometrically similar RC specimens, and they found the size effect was measurable for the descending part of the load–displacement diagram. Ş ener et al. (2004) also carried out some experimental work on the size effect in RC columns. Moreover, the efforts in McGregor (1988) and Nilson et al. (2010) that were made in understanding the behavior of RC columns also illustrated the size effect in RC columns. Kani (1967) pointed out the importance of the size effect in shear, and he clearly demonstrated that, as the depth of the beam increased, the shear stress at failure decreased. Afterward, Bažant and Kazemi (1991), Bažant and Yu (2005a, b), Collins and Kuchma (1999), and Frosch (2000) conducted extensive experimental work, and their experimental results both illustrated the existence of size effect in RC beams. And they found that the obtained shear strength of RC beams of large sizes was small than that in the ACI shear design procedures (Bažant and Kazemi, 1991; Bažant and Yu, 2005a, 2005b).

All these efforts have showed the presence of a significant size effect in RC members. However, because of the limitations of experimental costs and conditions, the sizes of these tests are still relatively small. For instance, the sizes for the smallest cross section of the RC columns used in the experiments (Bažant and Kwon, 1994; Ş ener et al., 2004) were less than 300 mm. Therefore, whether the size-effect law proposed by Bažant and Planas (1998) is appropriate for larger RC members, e.g. sizes of 500, 600 or even 1000 mm, needs to be further inspected with experimental verification. Recently, the present authors have carried out some experimental investigation on a series of RC members of larger sizes, including columns, beams, and connections. In the RC column tests, the maximum sizes for the smallest cross section of a RC column used get to be 800 × 800 mm2. The details of these experimental efforts would be reported in other articles. Nevertheless, as the test was costly, only a smaller number of the test samples were conducted and thus the number of the available data was relatively less. It was hard to qualify the size effect of RC members because of the small amount of data and the relatively large scatter of test data. As we all know, it is unrealistic to conduct a great amount of large-size experiments for the study on the global mechanical properties and failure behavior of RC members.

Since experimental studies of mass concrete and concrete structures are difficult and expensive, modeling and simulations are getting more attractive as alternatives. Finite element simulation has become a powerful and effective analysis approach for the investigation on failure process and macroscopic mechanical properties of RC structures. The numerical tools are excellent, especially when used in a sensible way in combination with experiments (Man and Van Mier, 2011). The earliest publication on the application of the finite element method to the analysis of RC structures was presented by Ngo and Scordelis (1967). After this, the analysis of RC structures has enjoyed a growing interest and extensive work has appeared. Great progress has been made in the finite-element-based numerical analysis of plain and RC structures, for instance, the work in the literature (Carpinteri et al., 2012; Elwood, 2004; Fantilli et al., 2002; Junior and Venturini, 2007; Majewski et al., 2008; Phuvoravan and Sotelino, 2005; Saleh and Aliabadi, 1998; Wang and Teng, 2007; just to mention a few). Most of these investigations are established in the context of macro-scale models. However, these macro-scale models present some difficulties in describing correctly the physical mechanisms (fracture, damage, and transport mechanisms) taking place at finer scales and involving macroscopic observations (Benkemoun et al., 2010; Benkemoun et al., 2012). Recently, the stochastic distributions of material properties have been enriched into macroscopic model in some works (e.g. Bažant, 2004; Bažant and Novák 2000; Bažant et al., 2004) to reflect the damage process and failure behavior of concrete. In this kind of macro-model, the size effect can also be represented. Besides that, the stress-resultant-based macro-model was used to obtain the ultimate load design of RC frames, and the available results had a good agreement with experimental observations, e.g. in the work of Pham et al. (2012).

As known, the size effect and the process of softening are all related to the heterogeneity of the material in the domain within the structural dimension (Bocca and Bažant, 2001; Němeček and Bittnar, 2004). Only when the heterogeneous nature of the materials involved was correctly modeled, the size effects could be reliably accounted for in the numerical analysis of RC structures (Rios and Riera, 2004). As mentioned in Leite et al. (2004), the meso-mechanical methods, which are capable of reflecting the heterogeneity characteristic, have become effective numerical tools to describe the macroscopic mechanical behavior of concrete composite materials. However, the existing meso-mechanical models, such as the random particle model (Bažant et al., 1990), the lattice model (Grassl and Jirásek, 2010; Schlangen and Van Mier, 1992) and extended by Benkemoun et al. (2010), the confinement-shear lattice model (Cusatis et al., 2003), the fracture-based interfacial elements approach (López et al., 2008), and the random aggregate structure (RAS) (Wang et al., 1999; Wriggers and Moftah, 2006; Zhou and Hao, 2008), etc., pose forbidding demands on computer time. Bocca and Bažant (2001) studied the size effect in concrete columns using the micro-plane model that also was a kind of micro- or meso-mechanical model. Recently, Man and Van Mier (2011) have adopted the lattice model to study the size effect on concrete prisms subjected to three-point bending. However, these methods which belong to meso-scale analysis approaches still pose overwhelming computational difficulties. Accordingly, the major objective of this study is to develop an efficient and effective meso-mechanical method to simulate the failure behavior of RC members. In light of this intent, a meso-scale mechanical method, i.e. the meso-element equivalent method (MEEM) which was first proposed previously in Du et al. (2012) and could capture the heterogeneity character, was adopted for the simulation of the damage process and the macro-mechanical properties of RC members. To illustrate the reliability and accuracy of the present meso-mechanical approach, the numerical investigation on the damage process and the global mechanical properties of a RC column subjected to uniaxial compression was carried out. In the numerical simulation, two different models are used, i.e. a macro-scale homogeneous model and a meso-scale heterogeneous model. The simulation results obtained from the present meso-mechanical approach were compared with those of macro-scale model and experiments.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: Uniaxial compression tests are the most common tests for characterizing the strengths of concrete and concrete members. In order to investigate the overall mechanical properties as well as the size effect of RC members, lots of large-size RC tests were carried out, for instance, columns under axial and eccentric compressions, beams subjected to bending and shear actions, etc.

A series of experimental work on the uniaxial compressive performance of RC columns of different sizes have been conducted. Four groups of RC columns have been conducted to study a size effect in RC columns. The sizes of the four groups of RC columns were 200 × 200 × 900 mm3, 400 × 400 × 1800 mm3, 600 × 600 × 2700 mm3, and 800 × 800 × 3600 mm3, respectively. Generally speaking, the cross-sectional dimensions of RC columns are about 500–600 mm, and the concrete cover thickness is about 35 mm. In our tests, the concrete cover thickness for the RC column of sizes 800 × 800 × 3600 mm3 was taken as 40 mm, and this was regarded as a benchmark. To capture a size effect, the tests were designed based on similarity theory. Therefore, based on the geometric similarity ratio relationship, the concrete cover thickness for the RC column sized of 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 was set as 10 mm. Moreover, the concrete cover thickness for the RC columns of sizes 400 × 400 × 1800 mm3 and 600 × 600 × 2700 mm3 were 20 and 30 mm, respectively. The four columns had similar reinforcement ratios. The detailed experimental information and data of these tests which have been conducted at Beijing University of Technology in China would be reported in other article.

In this study, the tested RC column of sizes 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 is selected and analyzed. The details of the selected RC column are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1(a) shows the experimental device of the RC column under uniaxial compression, and Figure 1(b) schematically shows the specimen dimensions and the reinforcement. Two material regions of reinforcement have been distinguished, namely, the longitudinal and the transverse. The ribbed steel bar of Grade HRB335 was used as the longitudinal reinforcement, and the round steel of Grade HPB235 was adopted as the stirrups. The longitudinal reinforcement ratio ρ1 was 2.53%, and the volume fraction ρ2 of stirrups was 0.65%. In the test, the grade of concrete was C25, and the concrete cover thickness of the column was 10 mm. The size distribution of the aggregate particles adopted in the tests, which was determined by Chinese code design of concrete structure, was listed in Table 1. The modulus of elasticity Ec of the concrete was 32 GPa, which was obtained by a standard cubic compressive test, and the Poisson’s ratio νc of concrete was 0.2. The observed tensile strength ft and compressive strength fc, which were measured by direct tensile/compressive test methods were 2.75 and 30.2 MPa, respectively. The measured mechanical parameters of the reinforcing steel are as follows: the modulus of elasticity Es is 210 GPa and the Poisson’s ratio νs is 0.3. The yield stress of the longitudinal reinforcement and the stirrups were 335 and 235 MPa, respectively. An axial force was applied on the RC column by a multi-function electro-hydraulic servo loading test system. The obtained ultimate load (i.e. the load-carrying capacity) pu of the RC column was 1658 kN, and its corresponding vertical deflection Δs was 2.94 mm. The final crack pattern and the nominal stress–strain curve of the RC column to be discussed in details are presented in ‘Results and discussion’ section. Figure 1.
(a) Experimental device of a RC column; (b) dimensions and reinforcement of the RC column.
RC: reinforced concrete.
Table 1.
Aggregate size distribution adopted in the experiments.
Aggregate size (mm) 5–10 10–20 20–30
Volume fractions (%) 20 50 30

sec.title: Simulation of RC using the MEEM
Description of the MEEM
sec.p: Recently, the MEEM has been developed by the authors for the simulation of macroscopic mechanical properties of concrete (Du et al., 2012). Compared with other meso-scale analytical methods, the MEEM has acceptable accuracy and much higher efficiency taking advantage of the homogenized elements with much larger element size. The basic idea of the MEEM is illustrated as follows.

First, through the Monte Carlo method, a typical concrete RAS was generated consisting of randomly distributed aggregate particles, micro-cracks, pores, and mortar matrix filling the space between them, as shown in Figure 2(a). The concrete meso-structure shown in Figure 2(a) is then subdivided into a finite number of identical elements. Subsequently, an equivalent method of composite materials is used to determine the effective mechanical properties of each meso-element obtained. Each meso-element is processed equivalently to be a homogeneous and isotropic element, as shown in Figure 2(b). Owing to the difference of the volume fractions occupied by the constituents (such as aggregate particles, mortar matrix, micro-cracks, void, etc.) in different meso-elements, the effective mechanical properties of each meso-element are mutually distinct. The equivalent mechanical model (Figure 2(c)) corresponding to Figure 2(a) is established, in which each element is homogeneous and isotropic but with unique mechanical properties different from others. In Figure 2(c), different elements having different colors indicate different mechanical properties such as effective elastic modulus, Poisson’s ratio, strength, etc. Figure 2.
Basic idea of MEEM: (a) random aggregate model; (b) equivalent process; and (c) the equivalent mechanical model corresponding to (a).
Here, different colors represent different mechanical properties.
MEEM: meso-element equivalent method.

The MEEM has two issues that need to be solved, namely, the equivalence of meso-element and an appropriate element size. As mentioned before, the macro-nonlinearity and the size effect of concrete essentially originate from the heterogeneity of concrete meso-constituents. In the previous work (Du et al., 2012), the statistical analysis of elastic moduli of meso-elements was conducted, and the characteristic element size that could describe the global heterogeneity character of concrete was introduced. In other words, the macroscopic nonlinearity and the size effect of concrete can be captured when the characteristic element size is used to generate the meshes.

sec.title: Equivalent mechanical behavior of concrete meso-element
Constitutive relations of concrete meso-constituents
sec.p:
In this study, concrete is analyzed at meso-scale, and it is assumed to be a three-phase composite material including aggregates, mortar matrix, and the interfacial transition zone (namely so-called the ITZ). The macroscopic mechanical response of concrete composites will obviously depend on each phase properties as well as their spatial distribution and shapes (Benkemoun et al., 2010). Plasticity, continuum damage mechanics, fracture mechanics, elastic-damage, and combined plasticity and damage mechanics are the common theories that have been used for the description of concrete constitutive behavior (Kim and Abu Al-Rub, 2011). Each theory has its own advantages and disadvantages. The isotropic model with scalar damage variable has some difficulties to describe the irreversible deformations and the inelastic volumetric expansion in compression. However, continuum damage mechanics has proved to be an efficient tool for understanding and describing the structural evolutions and it has been widely utilized to describe the quasi-brittle concrete composites, e.g. in Bažant et al. (1990), Mazars and Pijaudier-Cabot, (1987), Tang et al. (2011), and Zhu et al. (2002). In this study, an isotropic damage model with constant residual strength is used to reflect the mechanical behavior of meso-constituents within concrete, as shown in Figure 3. The adopted constitutive relation is similar with that in the works of Bažant et al. (1990), Tang et al. (2006), Zhu et al. (2002), and Zhu et al. (2005). The aggregates and mortar matrix share the same constitutive law, and they are merely assigned with different mechanical parameters. This isotropic damage model has been demonstrated to well represent the mechanical properties of concrete meso-constituents as well as the macroscopic response and failure process of concrete (Du et al., 2012; Tang et al., 2011; Wriggers and Moftah, 2006). In damage mechanics, the elastic modulus of material may degrade gradually as damage processes, and here the elastic modulus of damaged material is expressed as (1)E= {(1-D+)E0For tensile damage(1-D-)E0For compressive damage in which D+ and D- denote the damage variables for tensile damage and compressive damage, respectively, E and E0 are, respectively, elastic moduli of the damaged and the undamaged materials. They are all scalars because the material damage is assumed to be isotropic and elastic. Figure 3.
The elastic damage-based constitutive behavior under uniaxial stress condition for concrete meso-constituents (aggregates and mortar matrix).

The damage variables D+ and D- range from zero for the undamaged material to one for totally damaged material. According to the constitutive behavior in Figure 3, the damage variables, D+ and D-, respectively, have the following form as (2)D+= {0,ɛ≤ɛt01-η-λη-1ɛt0ɛ+1-λη-1ɛt0<ɛ≤ɛtr1-λɛt0ɛ,ɛtr<ɛ≤ɛtu1,ɛ>ɛtu
(3)D-= {0,ɛ≤ɛc01-η-λη-1ɛc0ɛ+1-λη-1ɛc0<ɛ≤ɛcr1-λɛc0ɛ,ɛ>ɛcr where subscripts ‘t’ and ‘c’ represent tension and compression, respectively; ɛ0 the strain at the elastic limit; ɛr denotes the residual strain, ɛr=ηɛ0, η the residual strain coefficient; ɛu the ultimate tensile strain, ɛu=ξɛ0, and ξ the ultimate strain coefficient. In Figure 3, ft and ftr are, respectively, the uniaxial tensile and the residual tensile strengths, ftr=λft, λ signifies the residual strength coefficient; fc and, fcr are, respectively, the uniaxial compressive and the residual compressive strengths, fcr=λfc. Here, it is assumed that the magnitude of the residual strength coefficient under uniaxial compression is same with the one under uniaxial tension. This is similar with the works in Tang et al. (2006), Zhu et al. (2002), and Zhu et al. (2005). From Figure 3, it can be seen that after reaching the tensile strength, the materials (i.e. aggregates and mortar matrix) will enter the softening stage. As the damage and the deformation increase gradually, the load-carrying capacity of the material continues to decrease until the overall deformation reaches a specific value (i.e. the residual tensile strain ɛtr). Then, it is believed that the material has some constant bearing capacity (namely, the residual tensile strength ftr) before the deformation reaches its ultimate tensile strain ɛtu. As the deformation continues to increase, it is considered that the material will be completely broken and it cannot bear any load. However, for the compressive case, it is assumed that the material could always have the residual compressive strength fcr after the deformation reaches the corresponding residual compressive strain ɛcr.

sec.title: Effective constitutive relations of meso-elements
sec.p: When the MEEM is utilized to study the damage and failure behavior of concrete and concrete structures, the equivalent mechanical properties of concrete meso-elements should be determined by an equivalent method of composite materials. In the previous work (Du et al., 2012), concrete was regarded as a two-phase composite medium composed of aggregates and mortar matrix, and the classical parallel model was adopted to calculate the effective mechanical properties of concrete meso-elements. The ITZ which has been demonstrated to play a critical role in modeling, the failure behavior of concrete composites (e.g. Akçaoğlu et al., 2005; Brancherie and Ibrahimbegovic, 2009; López et al., 2008; Zhou and Hao, 2008) was not considered in the previous analysis. For this reason, the other work (Du and Jin, 2012a) has considered the influence of ITZs on the failure behavior of concrete composites. In this study, the effect of ITZs on the global mechanical properties of concrete was also taken into account.

Farran (1956) observed that the porosity in the vicinity of sand grains was larger than that in the cement paste far from the sand grains. The ITZ is essentially characterized by a higher porosity and a gradient of the anhydrous and hydrated phases. Ollivier et al. (1995) has found the fact that the excess of porosity is both the cause and the consequence of the existence of the ITZ. Furthermore, according to the work in Kim and Abu Al-Rub (2011), it is assumed that the behavior of the ITZ, which has weaker mechanical properties, is similar to that of the mortar matrix and it is homogeneous across the ITZ’s thickness. Simply put, compared with the far-field mortar (here it means the cement paste far from the aggregate), the ITZ is essentially a thin layer, typically 10–50 µm thick, of the near-field mortar matrix with high(er) porosity. In light of this, the ITZ has been assumed to be a kind of mortar of high porosity in the work of Du and Jin (2012a). When the porosity in the ITZ zones is known, the effective mechanical properties of the ITZs, such as modulus of elasticity, Poisson’s ratio, and tensile/compressive strengths as well as their corresponding peak tensile/compressive strains can be easily obtained by the mechanical properties of mortar matrix. The quantitative relationships between porosity and these mechanical parameters have been derived and discussed in our previous work (Du and Jin, 2012b).

Concrete herein is regarded as a three-phase composite material composed of aggregates, mortar matrix and the bond between them (i.e. the ITZ zone). After the meshing of a concrete RAS, a typical ‘mesoscopic composite element’ composed of aggregate, mortar matrix, and the ITZs, can be obtained, as shown in Figure 4(a). In Du and Jin (2012a), the ‘two-step’ equivalent method was used to achieve the effective mechanical properties of a concrete meso-element containing the three-phase medium of aggregates, mortar matrix, and the ITZs. Subsequently, a simple description of the ‘two-step’ equivalent method is schematically shown in Figure 4, and it is illustrated as follows. Figure 4.
Equivalent process of a three-phase composite of concrete: (a) and (b) presents the first step and (b) and (c) are the second step of the ‘two-step’ equivalent method.

The first step is schematically shown in Figure 4(a) and (b). In this step, the unique intent is to determine the effective mechanical properties of the ‘Equivalent-M’ shown in Figure 4(b). The volume fractions occupied by each phase (i.e. aggregate, mortar matrix, and the ITZs) within every concrete meso-element should be determined first, and they are assumed to be, Pag, Pitz, and Pmo, respectively. Obviously, these volume fractions satisfy (4)pag+pitz+pmo=1

It is assumed that the porosity in the ITZ zones is ppores, so the total porosity ppores mo of the cement paste including near- and far-fields cement pastes (i.e. the equivalent-M) is (5)ppores mo=pporespitzpmo+pitz

When the porosity, the volume fractions of the ITZ, and mortar matrix within the concrete meso-element as well as the mechanical properties of mortar matrix were known, the quantitative relationship between porosity and the effective mechanical properties of the equivalent-M can be deduced according to the approach provided in Du and Jin (2012a). The effective bulk modulus Kmo * and shear modulus μmo * of the equivalent-M can be evaluated as (Du and Jin, 2012a) (6{\rm a})Kmo *=4Kmoμmo(1-ppores mo)4μmo+3Kmoppores mo
(6{\rm b})μmo *=μmo (1-(ppores mo)2 ) where Kmo and μmo represent the bulk and shear moduli of the mortar matrix, respectively. The effective modulus of elasticity Emo * and Poisson’s ratio νmo * can be calculated as (7)Emo *=9Kmo *μmo *3Kmo *+μmo *,νmo *=3Kmo *-2μmo *6Kmo *+2μmo *

According to the work of Du and Jin (2012a), the effective strength σ0 M and its corresponding peak strain ɛ0 M can be obtained, respectively, as (8{\rm a})σ0 M=σ0 mo [1-(ppores mo)2/3 ]
(8{\rm b})ɛ0 M=Emo [1-(ppores mo)2/3 ]Emo *ɛ0 mo where Emo is the elastic modulus of the mortar matrix, σ0 mo the tensile/compressive strengths of the matrix, and ɛ0 mo the corresponding peak strain.

When the strength and the peak strain in equations 8(a) and (b) was substituted by the residual strength and the residual strain, the effective residual strain and the effective residual strength can also be easily obtained. In light of the above derivation, the obtained equivalent constitutive behavior of the equivalent-M is similar with that of mortar matrix, while it has a weaker stiffness and strength, as shown in Figure 5. The elastic modulus, Poisson’s ratio, strength, and critical strain of the equivalent-M can be easily obtained according to equations (5) to (8). Figure 5.
Constitutive relationship of equivalent-M (equivalence of the first step).

It can be observed from Figure 4(b) that the mechanical behaviors of the aggregate phase and the equivalent-M are all deterministic. Then, the classical Voigt parallel model (Voigt, 1889) adopted previously in the work of Du et al. (2012) were selected to obtain the effective mechanical properties of the two-phase composite element of Figure 4(b). This is the second step for the determination of the effective mechanical properties of the three-phase composite element shown in Figure 4(a). For a detailed discussion about the parallel homogenization method, see the work of Du et al. (2012).

The obtained constitutive behavior of the concrete meso-element of Figure 4(c) is the equivalent mechanical behavior of the ‘mesoscopic composite unit’ of Figure 4(a). The piecewise linear constitutive models for both the case of the two-phase and three-phase composite medium are schematically shown in Figure 6. The tension and compression share the same constitutive curve shape, while the stress–strain value is positive for tensile case and negative for compressive case. The equation of the piecewise linear constitutive model, for the case that concrete is assumed to be a three-phase composite medium, has the form as follows (9)σ= {EB 1ɛɛ≤ɛB 1=ζɛ0 moσB 1+EB 2·(ɛ-ɛB 1)ɛB 1<ɛ≤ɛB 2=ɛ0 agσB 2+EB 3·(ɛ-ɛB 2)ɛB 2<ɛ≤ɛB 3=ζɛr moσB 3+EB 4·(ɛ-ɛB 3)ɛB 3<ɛ≤ɛB 4=ɛr agσB 4ɛ>ɛB 4=ζɛr ag where ɛB 1, ɛB 2, ɛB 3, and ɛB 4 represent the four strains corresponding to the curve turning point of the constitutive model; EB 1, EB 2, EB 3, and EB 4 signify the four equivalent tangent moduli of the broken lines, and their magnitudes can be calculated by the ITZ porosity and the volume fraction occupied by aggregates, mortar matrix, and the ITZs; σB 1, σB 2, σB 3, and σB 4 are the four stresses corresponding to the four strains ɛB 1, ɛB 2, ɛB 3, and ɛB 4; ζ has the following form (Du and Jin, 2012b) (10)ζ=2+φ-φνmo2(1-φ2)(1-φ2/3) where φ is the porosity and νmo the Poisson’s ratio of the matrix. In Figure 6, f1 eff and f2 eff mean the effective strengths (including tensile and compressive strengths) of concrete meso-element for two-phase and three-phase cases, respectively. Figure 6.
Equivalent constitutive model of concrete meso-element.

Under uniaxial compressive loading, concrete acts in a brittle manner and compressive damage occurs, and the main failure mechanism of concrete is crushing in compression. For the sake of simplicity, the maximum tensile strain criterion and the maximum compressive principal strain criterion are adopted at the same time to describe the failure behavior of concrete. That is to say, the concrete element failure occurs when the maximum compressive principal strain reaches the critical compressive peak strain, or the maximum tensile principal strain achieves the critical tensile peak strain of the element. For concrete-like brittle materials, this law holds true for low-confinement conditions (Tang et al., 2006; Zhu et al., 2005). The MEEM combined with the equivalent piecewise linear constitutive model was validated (Du and Jin, 2012a) and had been successfully utilized to study the failure behavior of concrete (Du et al., 2012).

sec.title: Mechanical behavior of reinforcement
sec.p:
The mechanical properties of reinforcing steel, unlike concrete, are generally not dependent on external environment condition and time. In this study, an ideal elastic–plastic constitutive model used widely (for instance, Ibrahimbegovic et al., 2010; Saleh and Aliabadi, 1998) is adopted and it is sufficient to define the material properties for the numerical analysis of RC structures, as shown in Figure 7. The stress–strain curves for steel are generally assumed to be identical in tension and compression. The constitutive equation can be expressed as (11)σ= {fyɛ>ɛyEsɛ-ɛy≤ɛ≤ɛy-fyɛ<-ɛy in which Es denotes elastic modulus of reinforcing steel, fy yield stress, and ɛy critical yield strain. Figure 7.
Constitutive model of reinforcing steel material.

sec.title: Concrete and reinforcement interaction
sec.p: In general, three different approaches can be used in the modeling of reinforcing steel in a RC structure, namely, the distributed or smeared model (Maekawa et al, 2003; Palermo and Vecchio, 2003), the embedded model (Cunha et al., 2012; Saleh and Aliabadi, 1998), and the discrete model (Keuser and Mehlhorn, 1987; Ngo and Scordelis, 1967). The bond–slip behavior between reinforcing steels and concrete should be considered to describe the cracking space of concrete (Dominguez et al., 2005; Ibrahimbegovic et al., 2010). However, due to the limitations of computational complexity, the perfect bond was assumed in this study, i.e. without separation and slip. The embedded model is selected to study the effect of the reinforcement in the simulation of damage process of RC structures. In the embedded model, reinforcing steel is discretized into truss elements or beam elements. Simply put, the reinforcing steel is considered as an axial member built into concrete element such that its displacements are consistent with those of the host element. The interactions between reinforcing steel and concrete element are simply deduced subsequently.

In this study, the basic theory about the interaction is illustrated by applying a simple two-dimensional (2D) plane-model. Shown in Figure 8 is an arbitrary quadrilateral element with a reinforcing bar. The nodal force {FE } for nodes 1–4 can be written as (12) {FE }= [X1Y1X2Y2X3Y3X4Y4 ]T in which X means the horizontal force and Y the vertical force. Figure 8.
Finite element discretization of the embedded model.
The corresponding nodal displacement {δE } has the following form (13) {δE }= [U1V1U2V2U3V3U4V4 ]T in which U means the horizontal displacement and V the vertical displacement.

For a concrete element itself (i.e. without reinforcing steel), the element stiffness matrix [Kc ] takes the form (14) [Kc ]=∫-1 +1∫-1 +1BTDB |J |t dξdη where B denotes the matrix of shape function derivatives, D an elastic–plastic material stiffness tensor, the array J the jacobian matrix for the transformation, and t the thickness of an element.
Based on the virtual work theory, we can get (15) [FE ]= [Kc ] {δE }

The cross-sectional area, the length, and the elastic modulus of the reinforcing steel i–j shown in Figure 8 are set as A, l, and E, respectively. The angle formed between the steel and the horizontal axial (i.e. the global x-axial) is θ. Taking m=sinθ and n=cosθ, the element stiffness matrix [K¯s ] of the reinforcing steel can be obtained as (16) [K¯s ]=EAl [n2mn-n2-mnn2m2-mn-m2-n2-mnn2mn-mn-m2mnm2 ]

The nodal forces {F¯s } and displacements {δ¯s } of the reinforcing steel can be described as (\rm 17a) {F¯s }= [XiYiXjYj ]T
(\rm 17b) {δ¯s }= [UiViUjVj ]T
Accordingly, the following relationship can be obtained (18) {F¯s }= [K¯s ] {δ¯s }

According to the consistent displacement condition, we can establish the relationship between the nodal displacements {δ¯s } of the reinforcing steel and the nodal displacements {δE } of the element in the form (19) {δ¯s }= [R ] {δE } where [R ] is transformation matrix and it has the form (20) [R ]= [a1l10000a1l10000b1l20000b1l200a2l10000a2l1b2l20000b2l200 ]

Based on the equilibrium condition, equation (21) can be obtained as (21) [Ks ]= [R ]T[K¯s] [R ] where [Ks ] is the stiffness matrix that reinforcing steel contributes to the total stiffness matrix of an element. The reinforcing steel stiffness matrix in equation (21) are then assembled together with the concrete element stiffness matrix to form total stiffness [Ksc ] of the element (22) [Ksc ]= [Kc ]+ [Ks ]

Compared with the smear model as well as the discrete model for the simulation of the interactions between concrete and reinforcing steel, the embedded model reinforcing steels can be flexible arranged. Furthermore, the displacement degrees of freedom of reinforcing steel are eliminated because of perfect bond between concrete and steel, making the computational efficiency improved significantly. With this modeling approach, the concrete behavior is considered independently of the rebar.

sec.title: Finite element model for the RC column
sec.p: In this section, a homogeneous macro-scale model and a heterogeneous meso-scale model are, respectively, developed for the simulation of failure behavior of the RC column. In the macro-scale model, the material is assumed to be homogeneous and isotropic. In the meso-scale model, the concrete sample is modeled as a three-phase composite.

sec.title: Homogeneous macro-scale model
sec.p: Extensive work on the damage and failure behavior of RC structures has been conducted at macro-scale based on the hypothesis that concrete is isotropic and homogeneous, as mentioned previously in the introduction. At macro-scale, all variables are averaged over the representative volume element of concrete composites. As it is known, the response of a structure depends on a large extent on the stress–strain relationship of the constituent materials.

The material model for concrete must account for nonlinearity in concrete behavior, since softening behavior of concrete occurs when concrete reaches its strength. Furthermore, any realistic material model for concrete must consider the initiation and propagation of tensile cracks that contribute to the degradation of strength and ultimate failure of the concrete member. The concrete damaged plasticity model introduced by Lubliner et al. (1989) and further extended by Lee and Fenves (1998) was utilized to describe the mechanical behavior of concrete at macro-scale because the model can satisfies the requirements above. This constitutive model, which is designed for applications in which concrete is subjected to monotonic, cyclic, and/or dynamic loading under low confining pressures, has been extensively used in, e.g. Cui and Nakashima (2011) and Deb and Bhattacharyya (2010), which has been included in the ABAQUS package. In this model, tensile cracking and compressive crushing in concrete is modeled through an isotropic damage variable that degrades the elastic moduli which is assumed to be linear and isotropic as (23)σ=(1-D)D0 el:(ɛ-ɛpl) where D denotes isotropic damage variable and D0 el means undamaged isotropic linear elasticity tensor.

Softening plasticity, when it is deprived of a characteristic length, often leads to boundary value problems that are ill-posed and produce unreliable numerical solutions. However, it is generally accepted that Hillerborg’s (Hillerborg et al., 1976) fracture energy proposal is adequate to alley the mesh sensitivity for many practical purposes. In the present macro-model, therefore, it is utilized to characterize the evolution of concrete tension damage through a stress–displacement response rather than a stress–strain response. This insures mesh independent solutions even in the presence of softening material behavior due to the presence of a characteristic length, the characteristic length being related to the element geometry, and formulation (Deb and Bhattacharyya, 2010). The inelastic behavior of concrete is represented by isotropic tensile and compressive plasticity. Further details of the constitutive model for concrete can be found in, e.g. Deb and Bhattacharyya (2010) and Lee and Fenves (1998).

In the present FEM analysis of the RC column, ideal bond was assumed between concrete and steel. Concrete was modeled by eight-node linear 3D brick elements. In the macro-model, the mesh size was 10 mm, and the RC column was divided into 36,000 elements. The characteristic crack length in the FEM computation was set as 10 mm. The mechanical parameters for concrete and reinforcing steel in the present simulations have been outlined previously in ‘Experimental setup’. What should be emphasized here is that the present macro-model is different from that in the work Bažant (2004) and Bažant and Novák (2000). All macro-element have similar properties in the present macro-model, while in the work of Bažant (2004) and Bažant and Novák (2000), the stochastic macro-elements were used.

sec.title: Heterogeneous meso-scale model
sec.p:
The macro-mechanical properties of concrete depend on the properties of its constituent phases, i.e. aggregate, mortar matrix and the ITZ. Based on the Monte Carlo method, a 3D concrete RAS of sizes 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 was established, as shown in Figure 9(a). Similar with the work in the literature Wriggers and Moftah (2006), it is assumed that aggregate has a spherical shape for the sake of simplicity. The ITZs, i.e. the thin layers around aggregates, are regarded as an independent material with given geometry and mechanical properties. In this study, the popular ‘taken-and-place’ method is employed to generate the coarse aggregates. First, the size distribution of the aggregate particles is determined by following the Fuller’s curve. Subsequently, the aggregate particles are placed into the mortar matrix one by one at randomly determined positions in such a way that no overlapping with particles already placed. The approach to generate the distribution of aggregates has been widely used in, e.g. Zhou and Hao (2008) and Grassl and Jirásek (2010). The wet-screened concrete specimen shown in Figure 8(a) includes 45 pieces of medium stone (diameter D1 = 30 mm) and 438 pieces of small grains (diameter D2 = 15 mm). The aggregate volume fraction is 47%. Figure 9.
Finite element models of the RC column: (a) a RAS of plain concrete column; (b) meso-element equivalent model corresponding to (a); (c) reinforced frame; and (d) RC column.
RC: reinforced concrete; RAS: random aggregate structure.

In the previous work (Du and Jin, 2012a), it was found that the simulation results had great agreement with the experimental results when the ITZ thickness was set as 2 mm and the porosity was 15%. However, the determinations of the thickness and the mechanical properties of the ITZs are outside of the major scope in this study. In the present RAS, therefore, the thickness of the ITZs surrounding aggregates is assumed to be 2 mm, and the porosity of the ITZs is taken as 15%. According to the basic idea of the MEEM described previously, the equivalent meso-mechanical model corresponding to the RAS was built in Figure 9(b). This was implemented with FORTRAN codes. The reinforcement frame shown in Figure 9(c) was then embedded into the concrete specimen of Figure 9(b), and finally the finite element model of the RC column which could take the heterogeneity character into consideration were built, as shown in Figure 9(d). The concept of the characteristic element size was introduced in the previous work (Du et al., 2012) to describe the statistical properties of the moduli of elasticity of concrete meso-elements. The non-homogeneous behaviors of concrete can be fully explained when the characteristic element size is taken as the mesh size of concrete at meso-scale. Taking the characteristic element size of the wet-screened concrete as the mesh size, i.e. 10 mm (Du et al., 2012), the whole plain concrete column is discretized into 36,000 identical hexahedral elements. The equivalent piecewise constitutive model shown in Figure 6 was used to describe the mechanical properties of concrete meso-elements. The equivalent constitutive model was implemented with FORTRAN codes and embedded into the commercial software ABAQUS. In Figure 9(d), different elements having different colors represent different mechanical properties such as effective elastic modulus, Poisson’s ratio, effective strength, etc. The mechanical parameters of the concrete meso-constituents including aggregates and mortar matrix are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Material parameters of concrete meso-constituents adopted in the analysis.
Materials Mortar matrix Aggregate
Young’s Modulus, E (GPa) 30 50
Poisson’s ratio, ν 0.22 0.16
Tensile strength, ft (MPa) 2.5 6.0
Compressive strength, fc (MPa) 30 80
Residual strength coefficient, λ 0.1 0.1
Residual strain coefficient, η 4 5
Ultimate strain coefficient, ξ 10 10

The reinforcement embedded into the concrete specimen is partitioned by the bar element, and the 1D stress–strain curve for the steel element is idealized. To capture the buckling phenomena of the longitudinal steel, geometrically nonlinear beam elements are used. While for the transverse reinforcement, the truss elements are adopted to reduce computational effort. The ideal elastic–plastic constitutive model shown in Figure 7 is used to describe the mechanical behavior of the reinforcing steel, and the well-known von Mises yield criterion is used.

In the present meso-simulations, when the damage evolution induces softening, the damage model in the foregoing local form loses objectivity and leads to pathological mesh sensitivity. The interaction between the rebars and the concrete element tends to reduce the mesh sensitivity, provided that a reasonable amount of tension stiffening is introduced in the concrete model to simulate this interaction.

sec.title: Boundary and loading conditions
sec.p: The RC specimen shown in Figure 9 is subjected to uniaxial compression along the z-axis (vertical), and it is loaded under displacement control, i.e. in the form of prescribed displacements at the loading points. Vertical displacements are prescribed to all nodes of the upper and lower faces of the specimen, with value equal to zero at the lower edge, and to a progressively increasing positive value for the upper edge. Other surfaces are left free. The present analyses adopt an incremental-iterative algorithm, and the Newton–Raphson method was utilized for the solution of nonlinear equations.

sec.title: Failure process of macro-scale model
sec.p:
At the macro-scale, the macroscopic responses of the RC column shown in Figure 7 were simulated under uniaxial compression. The numerical calculations were implemented using the commercial program ABAQUS. Figure 10 shows the damage and failure process of the RC column. In Figure 10, the term ‘DAMAGEC’ means the compressive damage. The damage factor D always was used to represent the degree of damage and failure, for instance, it denotes intact when D is equal to zero, while it means completely destroyed when D = 1. Here, it is assumed that the concrete specimen is seriously damaged when D reaches or exceeds 0.9. In Figure 11, the gray zones are the seriously damaged areas. From Figure 11, it can be noticed obviously that the damage and failure concentrates in the middle height of the RC column. With the increase of the external loading, the damage and failure zones grow gradually and concrete at the central surface starts to flake or spall. Finally, the RC column loses its load-carrying capacity and then it is destroyed. Figure 10.
Compressive damage process of the RC column obtained from macro-scale simulation.
RC: reinforced concrete.
Figure 11.
Damage process of the RC column obtained from a meso-scale simulation, and in the contours the gray regions mean that the maximum compressive principal strain has reached and exceeded the critical peak strain.
RC: reinforced concrete.

sec.title: Failure process of meso-scale model
sec.p: Using the present MEEM, the damage and deformation behavior of the RC column was investigated at the meso-scale. As known, the main failure mechanism of concrete or concrete components is crushing in compression. Figure 11 shows the maximum compressive principal strain contours of the RC column under uniaxial compression at different loading stages. These contours visually illustrate the whole damage process of the RC column. In these contours, the dark gray regions represent that the maximum compressive principal strain of the concrete meso-element has reached or exceeded the critical peak strain corresponding to the element equivalent compressive strength, namely, the element failure occurs. Unlike the results of the macro-scale model, the results obtained from the present MEEM can reflect the randomness of damage distribution, because the non-homogeneity of concrete meso-constituents has been taken into account. Due to the differences in the effective strength between each meso-element, the accumulated deformation and the compressive stress concentration cause material damage or failure at the local weak(er) zones having smaller effective compressive strength, as shown in Figure 11(b). As the applied load increases gradually, the damage emerges constantly at the undamaged area, and the damage zone expands gradually, as shown in Figure 11(c) and (d). The following compressive deformation concentrates in the most serious damaged region, for instance the middle surface of the concrete column. The global stiffness of the RC column declines and the overall negative stiffness behavior arises. This causes the damage accumulation up to the macroscopic crushing and the RC column loses its load-carrying capacity at last, as shown in Figure 11(e) and (f).

Furthermore, it can be concluded from Figure 11 that the deformation process and the failure behavior of RC column are associated with complicated progressive failures, as characterized by initiation, propagation, and coalescence of the local damage because of the heterogeneity of concrete, and the heterogeneity character leads to the macroscopic nonlinearity.

Besides that, it can be known that after reaching the load-carrying capacity of the RC column, the external load–displacement curve of the RC column declines gradually with the increase of the axial deformation, which speeds up the development of fracture and the peeling of the concrete cover layer. Then, the transverse strain of the RC column increases at the same time the stirrups start to bulge outward, while the RC column still can bear the external load due to the constraint of the stirrups. When the applied load continues to increase, lots of concrete blocks flake and slump, and some longitudinal reinforcements buckle (see, e.g. Figure 12(a)), and the stirrups at the middle height of the concrete column may reach their tensile strength and then the necking fracture occurs (Figure 12(b)). The buckling behavior of longitudinal reinforcement was also reported in Němeček and Bittnar (2004). The numerical observations of the reinforcement obtained from the present MEEM at meso-scale are described in Figure 12(c). It can be noticed that the simulation results are consistent with the experimental observations shown in Figure 12(a) and (b). Figure 12.
Response of the reinforcement: (a) longitudinal reinforcement buckles; (b) the stirrups of the middle height have a necking fracture; and (c) the numerical result by the present meso-mechanical method.

sec.title: Comparison of numerical and experimental results
sec.p: The numerical computations of the RC column sized of 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 were carried out by a standard PC with an Intel i3-2120 CPU and a memory of 2 GB. The calculation time for the macro- and meso-simulations is about 1.2 and 3 h, respectively. Compared with macro-model, it is obvious that the computation of the present meso-model is time consuming.

A comparison on the final failure pattern of the RC column was made in Figure 13 between the experimental observations, the macro-scale results, and three meso-scale results. Shown in Figure 13(a) and (b) are the final failure patterns of the RC column obtained from the experimental observation and the macro-scale analysis, respectively. Figure 13(c) shows three final failure patterns available from the present MEEM with three different aggregate arrangements at a constant volume fraction. It can be noticed from Figure 13 that the meso-scale simulation results (Figure 13(c)) are comparable with the experimental observations. It can be observed from Figure 13(b) that the available simulation results from the macro-scale method can represent the fact that the damage accumulates seriously in the middle height of the RC column. However, the damage distribution within the RC column is symmetrical, which cannot reflect the discreteness and the non-homogeneity of the concrete mechanical properties. Moreover, in the meso-scale model, the non-uniform spatial arrangements of aggregate in the RC column may produce serious damage in the column foot or other regions (Figure 13(c)), which cannot be obtained from the macro-scale analysis. Figure 13.
Final failure patterns of the RC column: (a) experimental observation; (b) macro-scale result; and (c) three results from the meso-scale analyses with different aggregate distributions.
RC: reinforced concrete.

A comparison between the numerical simulations and the experimental results is shown in Figure 14, in which the nominal stress–strain relations of the RC column are plotted. In this study, the average stress is drawn by summing nodal vertical reactions and dividing by the area of top surface, and the nominal strain is calculated as prescribed displacement divided by the height of the concrete column. Figure 13(a) shows the comparison of numerical and experimental results for the RC column of sizes 200 × 200 × 900 mm3. In order to illustrate the rationality and accuracy of the present meso-mechanical method more fully, the global mechanical response of another RC column of sizes 400 × 400 × 1800 mm3 has also been investigated. Also, the numerical and experimental results are plotted in Figure 13(b). Figure 14.
Nominal stress–strain relationship of the RC column: (a) the RC column of sizes 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 and (b) the RC column of sizes 400 × 400 × 1800 mm3.
RC: reinforced concrete.

From Figure 14, it can be seen that at the early stage of the applied loading, the global deformation is linear because all the concrete meso-constituents are in the linear elastic state. This is followed by a gradual slight softening up to the concrete overall compressive strength, at the time the global stiffness of the RC column drops to zero. Beyond the compressive strength the RC column, stress–strain relation exhibits a strain softening until failure takes place by crushing.

For both the two columns, it can be found obviously from Figure 13(a) and (b) that the meso-curves (i.e. the solid lines) are almost overlapped with the experimental curves before the peak stress. While the macro-scale curves (i.e. the blue solid line with solid dots) have some differences with the experimental curves, especially for the RC column of larger sizes. After the peak stress (i.e. the nominal compressive strength), it can be seen that the macro- and meso-scale curves are all not very consistent with the experimental curves. However, it can be noticed that the meso-scale results are larger than the macro-scale results after the peak stress, and the meso-scale results are much closer to the experimental results. Moreover, it can be concluded from the meso-results that the positive effect of stirrups in a post-peak regime can be well reflected. To sum up, it can be concluded that the present meso-mechanical method can well simulate the deformation process of the two RC columns. The observed nominal uniaxial compressive strengths of the two RC columns sized of 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 and 400 × 400 × 1800 mm3 were 41.45 and 37.425 MPa (the measured load-carrying capacity in the test for the two columns were 1658 and 5988 kN), respectively. For the smaller RC column, the compressive strengths obtained from the meso-scale analysis, respectively, were 40.43, 39.21, and 41.32 MPa; and for the larger one, the compressive strengths were 36.43, 36.77, and 37.28 MPa, respectively. Obviously, they have a good agreement with the experimental data. This also demonstrates the accuracy and the rationality of the present meso-scale mechanical approach. Moreover, it can be noticed obviously from the comparison between the two RC columns of different sizes that the uniaxial compressive performance of RC columns has a significant size effect. The larger size the RC column has, the smaller the compressive strength and peak strain of the column is.

The global deformation process of the RC column sized of 200 × 200 × 900 mm3 with five different mesh sizes, i.e. 1, 2, 4, 8, and 10 mm was investigated, and the available nominal stress–strain curves were plotted and shown in Figure 15. The descending parts of the curves were distinct, but the difference was not large. In addition, it can be found from Figure 15 that the obtained macroscopic compressive strengths were almost the same. Perhaps, this is because the interaction between the rebars and the concrete element tends to reduce the mesh sensitivity. Nevertheless, because the present damage model is local, the obtained results are mesh dependent. Therefore, some non-local damage models, such as those in the works of Grassl and Jirásek (2006) and Pijaudier-Cabot and Bažant (1987) should be developed and adopted in future numerical computations. To sum up, it can be concluded from the above analysis that compared with the macro-scale model, the present meso-scale mechanical model is capable of capturing the important characteristic of the concrete heterogeneity and thus, could realistically reflect not only the damage process and the failure behavior of RC components but also the failure process, such as the buckling behavior of the longitudinal reinforcement, the necking fracture of the stirrups, the broken positions of concrete, etc. Furthermore, it can be noticed that the present meso-mechanical approach can be extended to investigate the size effect in RC members. However, there are some issues still needs to be further solved, especially the computational efficiency and the mesh sensitivity in the present meso-simulations. Figure 15.
Comparison of the macroscopic deformation of the RC column on five different meshes.
RC: reinforced concrete.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, the MEEM proposed previously is utilized to study the damage and deformation process of RC structures. A RC column subjected to uniaxial compression is studied using both the macro-scale and the meso-scale models to illustrate the rationality of the present meso-mechanical approach. The simulation results indicate that the deformation and failure behavior of the RC column are associated with complicated progressive failures, as characterized by initiation, propagation, and coalescence of the local damage because of the concrete heterogeneity. The present meso-scale approach can well simulate not only the macroscopic mechanical properties of RC columns but also the failure process, such as the buckling behavior of the longitudinal reinforcement, the necking fracture of the stirrups, the broken positions of concrete, etc. A comparison is made between the experimental observations, the macro-scale results, and the meso-scale results. Results of the simulation at meso-scale are in good agreement with experiments in both the failure patterns and the global mechanical properties. This indicates the validity and accuracy of the present MEEM. Furthermore, it can be found from the numerical results that the distributed cracking engenders an energetic size effect, namely, decrease of the nominal strength of structures with increasing structure size.
To sum up, the present meso-mechanical method, which can well simulate the global deformation process of RC columns, can be extended to investigate the size effect in RC members.

However, there are still some issues that need to be further investigated, for instance, the size effect in the RC structures and the bond slip behavior between concrete and reinforcing rebar, as well as the mesh dependency in the meso-simulations, etc. The detailed investigation on the size effect in these RC structures will be carried out in our future work. In addition, non-local damage approaches should be used in future computations in order to limit strain localization and to circumvent mesh sensitivity associated with strain softening. The failure criterion of concrete meso-elements used in this study is hard to consider the behavior of the concrete under complicated loading states. And this also needs to be further studied.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 50838001), the National Key Basic Research and Development Program of China (No. 2011CB201600), and the Doctoral Fund of Innovation (YB201207). The support is gratefully acknowledged.
